medical_history.chief_complaint: Anemia and laboratory evidence of increased iron stores.
medical_history.history_of_present_illness: The patient was admitted one month prior with pain in the left lower abdominal quadrant radiating to the back, associated with headache and shortness of breath. Symptoms progressed, leading to concern about iron overload syndrome. A thrombosed left ovarian vein was discovered. Patient's symptoms improved post-treatment.
medical_history.past_medical_history: The patient had a history of pneumococcal meningitis and omphalitis at two months of age, and gastrointestinal bleeding due to portal hypertension diagnosed two years later, which led to splenorenal shunt with splenectomy at age five. No further episodes of bleeding or anemia since then.
medical_history.family_history: The patient's father and paternal aunt had been diagnosed with Diamond–Blackfan anemia; the father required a single transfusion at birth. One sister was diagnosed with Diamond–Blackfan anemia and treated with corticosteroids and transfusions, later requiring iron-chelation therapy. The patient's mother had anemia as a child and was said to have β-thalassemia trait.
medical_history.social_history: The patient was a non-smoker (discontinued smoking), consumed alcohol rarely, and had no history of illicit drug use. She worked in an office and was in a monogamous relationship.
